description:
Wing Leader is an exciting new game system of large scale aerial combat in World War II. Based on a unique side-scrolling view, in which altitude is clearly visible, players can recreate the great air battles of the war.

This first volume, Wing Leader: Victories 1940-1942, includes scenarios for the Battle of Britain, Malta, Coral Sea, Midway, North Africa, and Stalingrad. Future games will expand the system to the late war.

Players fly squadrons and flights, attempting to intercept raids or fend off marauding fighters in fast-playing games that take between 90 and 120 minutes.

Wing Leader takes a new look at aerial warfare, incorporating aircraft, altitude, and weather in a way never seen before!

The second game in the series is Wing Leader: Supremacy 1943-1945. 
For the Second Edition (version 2.2) see Wing Leader: Victories 1940-1942 (Second Edition).

Catalogue was first published in Game Market Osaka 2014.


				
				
					Can you figure out what your partner wants?

				
				
					From the rules:(The basic game is for two people)



Get some catalogs or magazines. 
Put the Love Tokens and Markers on the table.
Each player takes one set of cards.


The Ranking Player chooses a page of the catalog and decides on a theme.

The Guessing Player randomly places 7 markers on the page's photos (brown side facing up).

ã€€1. The Ranking Player places the cards on the table face down in order.

ã€€2. The card ranked number 4 is turned face up as a hint for the Guessing Player.

ã€€3. The Marker which corresponds to rank 4 should be flipped to the green side. (Any time a card is revealed, flip the corresponding Marker too!)


The Guessing Player tries to guess the Ranking Player's number 1 choice.
The Guessing Player can ask questions, but whether to answer or not is up to the Ranking Player.
The Guessing Player plays the card from his hand which has the symbol he thinks the Ranking Player chose for number 1.


The Ranking Player opens the card with the same symbol as the one the Guessing Player showed.
Was it number 1?


If the Guessing Player guessed correctly, 
he gets a Love Token. If not, he gets nothing.


The Guessing Player continues to guess the 2nd and 3rd choices, and so on.

When the Ranking Player has only one card left, the game is finished.
(The highest score is 5 points. The last card is obvious, so you don't get any points for it.)


You can high five each time you get a Love Token!


Now the Guessing Player and Ranking Player switch roles.


The total number of Love Tokens collected becomes the couple's score.

Games and exercises for brain-fair training. Train playfully your pictorial imagination.

Erweitern Sie Ihr Potential durch Gehirn-gerechtes Training.

There is a booklet from Vera F. Birkenbihl for training. Your partner on the way to a brain-right using your brain-potential. Also there are games to play. 1. Difference (for concentration) :  2. Play with a correspodence in cipher. 3. Undercover mit 36 cards like a memory game.The cards are open. 6 wooden small plates are to cover 6 cards. Each plate with another colour. You play with a dice with the six colours of the plates and have to say what picture is under the plate.

Difference: is a placement game with 4 laying boards and 36 picture cards for 2-4 players. You have to lay down pictures on a board (with the same pictures). The pictures only have small differences. The first player has his cards stored calls stop. With the control film is controlled. For each correct card there is a point. Four rounds, so everyone plays with each panel. The points are added up. The player with the most points wins.

Undercover: is a memory game with 36 cards, 6 wooden discs and a cube. The aim of the game is to remember which motifs of ancient cultures are covered under the individual colored wooden discs, then color cubes with the correct predictions to collect after roll a most picture cards. The wooden plate is then placed on another subject. The cards are open. 6 wooden small plates are to cover 6 cards. Each plate with another colour. You play with a dice with the six colours of the plates and have to say what picture is under the plate.

Another game of the Ravensburger Think Series, a brainteaser/mental exercise game-series. These games are good for mental training, e.g. in creativity, concentration, imagination, logic and so on.

Designer of GEHIRNPOTENTIAL is Vera F. Birkenbiehl.
Designer of DIFFERENCE is Elisabeth Richter.
Designer of UNDERCOVER is Heinz Meister.

Pleasant Prospect Farm is yours! Will you keep animals, which are valuable but require a fenced paddock? Will you grow crops? Or diversify and offer camping facilities? Finally, a tractor will be a great help with ploughing and harvesting, but if you have campers they may not like the noisy machinery!

A card draft takes places where, each turn, players draw a card, play one card face up and one face down, then pass on the remainder. When seven cards have been played, they are scored. Animal cards give a higher score then crops, but only if they are combined with a paddock card. The score for tents is dependent on the size of the set. The tractor card increases the score for cereal and vegetable cards but reduces the score for tents.

Designed for the 2014 Microgame Print and Play Contest.

Alchimia — a land where the works of a single grand alchemist has caused alchemy to develop more quickly than other technology. The everyday lives of the people rely on the alchemy factories that this first pioneer built.

In Ars Alchimia, you work at one of these factories. As an overseer belonging to the Academy, you take orders from the people, gather resources, and transmute them — but you need to be more efficient than your competition.

The game lasts four rounds, with each round representing a year. Each round, players take turns placing one or more of their workers on one action they want to do: gather resources, take up an order, employ an assistant, or transmute at the alchemy forges. The trick is that the more workers on one spot, the less effective an action becomes; if you want to place workers on a spot where there are already some, you'll have to exceed the number of workers already there.

In the fast-paced game Robin, you have just joined Robin Hood's merry men in Sherwood Forest. You can help at the Sherwood Forest camp, rob travelers on the road to Nottingham castle, bring messages from Robin, and scout the neighborhood for information. The more risk you take, the higher the rewards — but take care because if you get too close to the castle, you'll need to go back and hide in the forest before the sheriff's guards can catch you!

You want to be the first to accomplish seven missions of the same type in order to become Robin's new lieutenant. Of course your friends want to become lieutenants, too, so you will have to be swift and daring to succeed before them.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Auckland, in New Zealand.

In Tavern Brawl, each player chooses 5 units which make up their very own adventuring party. The Tavern (game board) is created using modular tiles that can be arranged in many ways. Every turn players may activate up to three of their Units. When activated, a Unit can move, punch, or use its unique power. Each unit has a Life value and when it receives wounds equal to it, it's defeated, and removed from play. The first player to defeat the others Units wins the game!

- Easy to learn, Hard to Master
- Great for new Gamers and skilled ones
- No downtime as every turn is crucial for both players
- Average play time under 20 minutes!
- Immense replay value with hundreds of possible team combinations

The momonga (Japanese for flying squirl) siblings are leaving the nest, jumping from tree to tree and collecting food. Who will be the first to establish their own nest and win the game?

Players take turn swooping the velt momonga from the tree branch to the landing tree in the center. Your momonga lands successfully if it sticks to the landing tree, which is divided into 3 parts by 2 lines. Depending on where your momonga lands, you either move 1, 2 or 3 spaces on the circle tile surrounding the landing tree. If you land on a tile with a paw print, you collect a food by taking one of the outer circle tokens. If you land on a tile where there is another momonga already, you can steal a food from that player.
There are 5 different kinds of foods and the aim is to collect 4 different types. The place where you gathered the last of the required food tokens will be your nest. Next you have to go around the forest one more time to inform your friends of your new home. The first player to complete the circle and land exactly on their own nest, wins the game.

The game also includes leaf tokens. You can exchange a food token for a leaf token. A leaf token can be played for one of the following two actions:
1) You momonga is allowed to try one more jump.
2) When another player's momonga is making it's jump, you can blow from behind the landing tree to hinder them.

The rulebook contains a few optional rules to change the base game and some other game variants.

OBJECT:
Have the highest total score after five rounds of play.

GAME OVERVIEW:
In BID SIX, each round of play begins with one player rolling a set of six white dice and arranging them in a row in the middle of the table.  All players then use their own deck of 30 cards (28 bidding cards and 2 blocking cards) to win as many of the six dice as possible by placing one card next to each die.

The highest bidding card for each die wins that die and its points, unless someone plays a blocking card for that die.  A blocking card blocks ALL players from winning the die, including the person who played the blocking card. Used cards must be discarded at the end of each round.

If a player wins a “TRIPLE” (a group of any 3 dice) in a single round of play, they get to roll 1, 2, or 3 of the black dice for additional bonus points, depending on the numbers on the three dice in their TRIPLE.  Roll 1 bonus die for a BASIC TRIPLE (any three numbers), 2 dice for a STRAIGHT TRIPLE (numbers in sequence), and 3 dice for a THREE-OF-A-KIND TRIPLE (all the same number).

The player or team with the highest score after all five rounds of play (when all cards have been used) wins the game!

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from NRL, the National Rugby League

When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from 
New South Wales, Australia; limited Edition NSW Monopoly Boards to raise money for Childhood Cancer

Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Perth, Australia.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Western Australia; limited Edition to improve the lives of children and young people throughout Western Australia.

Doggerland Miniature Skirmish Game is a fast-play, skirmish-level fantasy miniature system that has been co-written by S.E. Lantry and Andrea Sfiligoi.

As with Songs of Blades and Glory, it uses an action-point system that requires no book-keeping. The rules are designed to be simple, fast and fun so that a mini campaign of several games can be played in a single evening.

The Basic Game follows closely to the SoBG model, i.e., the game includes statistics for 180+ monsters and heroes, and details to be able to create your own. Also there are campaign rules where your warband grows more powerful after every battle, and six basic scenarios.

Advanced Rules include the use of an expandable and customizable deck of cards used fro initiative, environmental effects, defence and building a result into historic proportions.

The game offers co-operative and competitive play Adventures, and can be played in 15mm and 28mm.

Funding for this Kickstarter project was canceled by the project creator on May 30 2014.
Interstellar Crisis is a skirmish miniatures space combat wargame set in the year 5318. It utilizes a unique movement deck and vector movement to simulate how ships would really move in space.

A childrens' game based on the story/song of Joey the Swamp Thing.  An auto-translated description:

"Coming clear and cold night, which is mainly for people from Prague campers around Vizovic very dangerous. Occur ideal conditions for Joey to come out of the dark swamp hunting. And for you, the hunter, comes the moment of truth. Attracted by the beauty of the chairman's daughter, the size of the local collective farm and a reward for the capture of Joey for a while and jumping into the fight, which is likely to lose. JoÅ¾inovy â€‹â€‹ingenious traps and JoÅ¾in you handled yourself before you say love Cak. To the right you owl hooted and bog you down oval stale cold. One last question. It is the good love you for it ...? JoÅ¾in swamp - Exciting board game with unexpected propadáváním into the swamp. Try to catch Joey in the original game from Ivana Mladek. PÅ™elstíte him? Can you avoid the sharp teeth while nezahuÄet in the swamp? Unique gaming principle, 3D game board and author Ivan Mládek guarantee that you will all be great fun. Contents: game board, 25 pieces (1 x JoÅ¾in, 3 x 8 color-coded hunters), 2 dice, instructions game is designed for 2-4 players from 5 years old. Made in the Czech Republic."

One player is the monster, and the rest are competing teams of hunters, who must avoid both being eaten by Joey, and sinking into the swamp.  Some of the board spaces are holes which open and close with hidden gears that are turned.

User summary:

A space-ship themed cooperative game. Players are crew on a derelict spaceship that has wandered in in a dangerous space zone. Game is played on the board that represent the space ship, with various stations such as the bridge, engine room, resting room and so on. On their turn, players roll a die to see what threat happens (ship breaks down, asteroids or space slime attacks), then may do one movement and one action; action depending on what station the player is – an action in the sensor room will increase the sensor system, an action on the bridge will navigate the ship.

All character have different stats in various actions, repairing, and endurance points, that may be used to strain the character for extra actions.

The goal of the game is to increase the sensor system enough so that the players manage to navigate out of the dangerous zone. Game is lost if any player dies, if the spaceship collides with an asteroid or if too many space jellyfish cling to the hull.

User summary:

A push-your-luck game with a deck building mechanism.

Players are criminals in a prison and try to dig their way out. All players start with a deck consisting of cards with numbers 0–3 (mostly 0), representing how far they've dug. Each round, players simultaneously reveal the first 3 cards of their deck, and then all players get in turn to choose to either go on digging or give up for the day. Those who give up for the day get a couple of benefits such as getting new cards for their deck and/or removing one of the cards they've revealed. Those who continue must turn over one of four guard cards, risking getting caught. If they get caught, they don't get any benefits for this round. If not caught, they get to reveal another 3 cards; rinse and repeat.

Once all have chosen to give up for the day, players put all revealed cards in any order they choose in their discard pile, and then place their discard pile face down beneath their deck, hence "programming" the deck.

The first player to be able to reveal 20 dig points in one and the same round wins the game.

User summary

A rather quick card game with a trick-taking mechanism, in which players try to play the lowest of a certain colour in order to score the card they played.

Players have a set of monsters numbered 1–10 on their hands. Each round, the starting player chooses 4 of 8 monster hunters that will hunt down monsters played each trick; these 4 cards are shuffled into a face down pile. Each trick, players play one card each of any colour and number, and then the top monster hunter card is revealed, and any cards that matches the conditions of the monster hunter are discarded. Of the remaining monsters, the lowest number of each colour are score, the rest discarded. Players can also discard cards from their hand to gain their special effects.

After three tricks, the monster hunter cards are re-gathered, re-chosen and the players play three rounds like this; the most points in their score pile wins.

ã‚·ãƒ¥ãƒ¬ãƒ¼ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ³ã‚¬ãƒ¼ã®çŒ« (Schrödinger's Cat) is a three-player card game in which the players must manage their hands so that it corresponds with the final outcome for the cat. Players start with eight cards in hand, with the cards being black or white with values 1-4. Playing a black card increases the chances of the cat being dead — and a white card for it being alive — but anything above 100% gets lowered by 100.

After six rounds, players win depending on the outcome of the cat and the two cards each player still has in hand.

In June 1942, forces of the Japanese Northern Army occupied Attu Island as part of its Midway campaign. Attu, at the far western end of the Aleutian Archipelago, was American soil. In May 1943, American forces landed on Attu to liberate it. They were unprepared for the tenacity of the Japanese defenders and the brutality of the environmental conditions. What was expected to be a week-long clean-up exercise became a month-long, nose-to-nose meat-grinder whose casualty levels would not be exceeded until Iwo Jima.

"War in the Wind: The Battle of Attu Island, 1943" is a low-to-moderate complexity wargame (roughly eight pages of rules) depicting the brutal combat and conditions on Attu. The design focuses on the challenges faced by the American forces in the form of extremely variable weather conditions and logistical hurdles posed by nearly insurmountable terrain. The Japanese must use these conditions to their advantage in order to survive the overwhelming American numbers.

In addition to the campaign game covering the entire battle, War in the Wind also includes three smaller scenarios focusing on separate phases of the battle.

Game Scale:
Turn: 1 day
Hex: 400 yards / 366 meters
Units: Platoon to Company

Game Inventory:
One 22 x 34" full-color mapsheet
Two dual-side printed countersheets (324 9/16" counters - includes 42 blanks)
One 20-page War in the Wind rules booklet
Two dual-side printed Player Aid cards
Three 10-sided dice

Complexity: Medium
Solitaire Suitability: High
Players: 1 or more
Playing Time: 1-10 Hours

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the Olympic Games 2012 in London, United Kingdom, equipped with special tokens.

This edition of Carcassonne: Wheel of Fortune includes the Bridges, Castles and Bazaars expansion.

Carcassonne: Wheel of Fortune is both a full replacement for the base game of Carcassonne and an expansion to the original base game. It includes 72 tiles, consisting of 63 tiles released in the original base game, 6 from Inns & Cathedrals, 1 from Traders & Builders and 2 from King & Scout. It also includes a special replacement start tile which depicts the Wheel of Fortune, a new mechanic unique to this edition of the game. The new start tile is the size of 16 tiles, arranged in a 4×4 square and is built using some of the tiles removed from the base game.

Nineteen tiles from the game have numbers printed on them allowing players to randomly spin the Wheel of Fate (between 1 and 3 spaces around the wheel). Otherwise, a player may choose to place a follower on the wheel if they decline placing a follower that turn. The results of the Wheel vary depending on which of the sixths of the wheel the pig lands on. Results vary from forcing all players to remove a follower from the board to rewarding the player who moves the pig with three bonus points. There are six outcomes in all.

Play of this game does not require ownership of any Carcassonne base game. All expansions are compatible with this game. This game can also be played with the base game as an expansion, using its wagon wheel watermark to differentiate it from the base game.

Bridges, Castles and Bazaars is the eighth expansion for Carcassonne. It allows players three new options while playing:

Bridges may be used to continue a road over a field tile, thereby allowing an incomplete road to technically run into a field segment. They are otherwise treated and scored just like roads.

Castle tokens are placed atop 2-segment cities and allow players a chance to cash-in on the next completed adjacent feature.

Bazaars are a new type of tile that allows players to auction off tiles in exchange for points.

Who's done what? You'll find out in the hilarious game of Pointing Fingers! You'll also find out how well you know your family and friends in this fast-paced question-and-answer game. Each person reads a question from one of the cards, then everyone else selects how often they've done it on their Truth Meters. Then you point out who you think has done it the most with your funny Foam Finger! If you're right, you score. Don't miss out on the big laughs and hilarious discoveries of the Pointing Fingers game!

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from 
V8 Supercars, a touring car racing category based in Australia.

TV series adaption 
Objective: be the first completing a set of
ingredients/tools to achieve a master degree regarding witchcraft.
 - moving by turns -
Move around the board according dice roll collecting the stuff you need (depending on the space you end your turn). There are 3 different sort of spaces: sorcery, character and chance. To increase your abilities you must find matching combinations.

Code Monkey Island is a family-friendly board game that introduces kids ages 8 and up to programming concepts used by real programmers. Code Monkey Island is a board game designed for families. It takes about a minute to learn the rules and 45 minutes to play, and exposes kids to fundamental programming concepts like control structures, data structures, Boolean logic and operators, and assignment and mathematical operations.

Step 1: Each player chooses their favorite tribe of monkeys, and sets them down in the corresponding Start Circle.
Step 2: Everyone is dealt 3 Rule cards.
Step 3: On their turn, a player draws 1 Rule card, and plays another card from their hand to move their monkeys forward.
Step 4: The first player to get all 3 of their monkeys around the island and into the banana grove wins!

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Bunnings, a company in Australia.

Swing is a crazy party card game for 3-8 mature players, published in 2014 by the Polish company Let's Play.

In the game, described by the publisher as "mental Kamasutra", the players' aim is to collect 30 Pleasure Points. They earn them by using Sex Positions cards (Actions, Counter-actions, Events and Special cards) to initiate a "virtual" intercourse with another player's character (they can be of different sexes and orientation). Other players can interrupt and prevent earning points by playing Counter-action cards, often with a humorous effect.

For adults only!

The match box was dropped and all the matches are mixed up. The goal of the game is to find as many matching pairs as possible. The game plays similar to the classic memory game Concentration, but there are a few twists.

Half of the cards will be face down and the rest will be face up. The start player will lay down the cards in a 3x3 grid. Each player should look at the cards as they are being put down, as it is important to remember the cards & placement. Just like in the classic memory game, the players try to find a matching pair. Whoever says "match!" gets a try. When the cards match, that player takes the cards, which will score at the end of the game. If 2 different cards are picked, these go to the discard pile and the player receives one of the yellow burning matches. If no one else sees another match, the remaining cards are reshuffled and the next player places them in the grid.

The game ends when all cards have been claimed, or if the 5 burning matches are in play. The player with the most cards wins.

The goal is to get to "De Admiraal", the municipality building with the least amount of dimes.

Everybody receives a start fund of 5 dimes to play with. If the bank is empty, it means everybody is out of luck until somebody needs to pay taxes again.

The unfortunate one who is broke can beg for money with the "rich" people. If that doesn't happen he or she needs to return a minimum of 15 blocks to a white space.

The game is influenced by a dice, chance cards challenges, tact, charm and experience.

No Shame Charades is the unclassy twist to the classic party game. Perfect for social adults with an unfiltered sense of humor.

The game comes with a 2 minute sand timer, 20 Game Changer cards and 480 phrase cards, each with it's own hilarious definition to help the one person that doesn't know what a "Rusty Trombone" is.
  
Phrases derive from 4 main topic areas: 
- today's pop culture(ish) (ex. "Anchorman", tiger blood, bath salts)
- dark matter (crack baby, kidnap)
- adult stuff (dry hump, walk of shame, morningwood)   
- general funny (brain fart, "sh*t hit the fan", explosive diarrhea)

There are 4 types of Game Changer cards - lose a turn, all play, charade with a beverage in one hand, and reverse the timer.

Each team takes 2 minute turns to act out as many phrase cards possible.  For every phrase correctly guessed, your team earns 1 point. If a card is passed, you lose a point.  At the end of each round, the other teams can earn a point by taking 1 correct guess at a card that was passed during the round.  Watch out for Game Changers - these cards will make you wish you\'ve never been born.  First team to 21 wins!

Simurgh is a game for 2-5 players who become heads of powerful clans in a fantastical world where humans and dragons live, hunt and go to wars together. As a head of a powerful family, each player will breed mighty dragons, make use of their special abilities, gather resources and try to make their house the most powerful by gathering the most Power Points. The game is played in a sequence of turns, with each turn allowing a player to perform 1 Main Action and any number of Free Actions. As a Main Action, a player will usually place a worker on an Action Space.

The workers (collectively known as Vassals) come in two types: Spearmen – young warriors of each house, and Dragonriders – noble warriors and hunters gifted with their own Simurgh steed. On their turn, each player will place one of their Vassals on an empty Action Space to gain resources, exchange their assets for Power Points, add new Vassals to their house or breed a new type of Simurgh.

During the game, players will collectively build the board by drawing and placing Action Tiles, each either providing new Action Spaces (some allowing any Vassals, some exclusively the Dragonriders), or creating an opportunity to score points for combinations of specific dragons in a player’s possession. When all the scoring spaces are filled with tiles, the game ends at the end of the round and Power Points are tallied.

The palace and gardens of Versailles, finalized under the rule of Louis XIV of France, are an architectural marvel of the world. In Versailles, players take the roles of architects and interior designers, working together to build and decorate the ensemble of Versailles, competing for the favor of the King. Players take turns moving one worker from a building site to an adjacent one, activating all the workers in the new location.

Despite simple rules, players develop complex strategies, gathering resources, building the puzzle-like palace, designing impressive decorations and learning new skills, all while waiting for the arrival of his Majesty.

A science vessel lands un an unexplored planet and a group of scientists sets out from the ship to gather data on the planet's history and wildlife, also encountering hostile aliens!

It will be up to you, as one of the science team members, whether to take the chance to collect more Data in the dangerous alien wilds, return to your Ship with the Data you've already collected, or strike out on your own to hunt the Aliens before they hunt you!

Also, when you return to the Ship, afraid to explore further, you can continue to be involved in the Mission by "analyzing" the data you've collected, using it to "bet" on the continuing Mission.

At the end of the game, after five Missions, players compare their Data totals, and the player with the most Data wins.

Strange Planet is a push-your-luck card game with elements of betting and set collection.

Roll with the punches!
There's a rowdy ruckus in the land of Leprechauns. 
Perhaps it's their penchant for porter, or maybe it's because they're giddy for gold. Either way, it's time to play. Pick up your Shillelagh and join in the frey.

Leprechaun is an all out battle for gold. It's a dice rolling game with a bit of press your luck. Players represent Leprechauns gathering gold coins, fighting over gold coins, and bolstering by drinking beer and gathering 4 leaf clovers.

Play consists of drawing 3 dice from the bag, choosing an action showing on the dice and then deciding if they wish to press their "luck of the Irish" by drawing additional dice from the bag, or they may bank what they have already acquired.

Gather, Fight or Bolster your way to the most gold to win.

It’s a well-worn story by now in the Land of Danger: An army attacking a castle. Somehow, though, the story keeps happening, and another bellicose mob has advanced on the imposing walls of someone else’s keep. The clash to control those walls is at hand. Lead the Blue attackers or the Red defenders, using clever card play and a touch of luck to control more sections of the wall than your opponent

The game consists of 54 cards -- 5 walls, a Red personal deck of 8 cards, a Blue personal deck of 8 cards, and a main deck of 33 cards.

Players take turns playing Archer, Cannon, Attack, Leader and Flag cards from their hands to the different walls. Archers & Cannons each have a strength value, and the player with the most total strength at a wall controls it. Attacks remove the opponent's cards, Leaders each have a unique ability that impacts how strength is calculated at a wall, and Flags lock down the control of a wall and trigger the end game.

The player controlling the most walls at the end of the game is the winner.

A monopoly (from Greek monos μÏŒνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεá¿–ν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from Victoria, a state in the south-east of Australia; limited Edition to improve the lives of children and young people throughout Victoria.

Lacrosse Blast is an "old-school" card-chart-and-dice simulation of pro lacrosse. Primarily designed as a solitaire game for sports board game hobbyists, it can also be played head-to-head, with each player making decisions for his team.

From the publisher:

We've taken our original lacrosse game, Crash and Scramble, and made it even better by adapting it to the same game engine that powers our popular hockey game, Hockey Blast. The result is a fast-playing, fun board game simulation of this cutting-edge pro sport that captures everything fans love about it: bone-jarring hits, acrobatic passes, rocket-fast shots, and amazing saves. YOU can re-create all the thrilling action of this "ahead-of the curve" sport, right in your own home, with Lacrosse Blast Pro Indoor Lacrosse Game!

Lacrosse Blast uses a possession-by-possession system of play that keeps things moving fast. The game uses the same easily-memorized chart structure and no-nonsense method of rating players as our hockey game. Players perform based on the presence--or absence--of various qualities like speed, power and skill. Each player is also rated for his ability in creating and/or taking away scoring opportunities, as well as for shots and assists, penalties, face-offs and injury. That means you'll get table-top performances which echo each player's real-life abilities without a bunch of calculations or math gymnastics. You'll see the great assist guys dishing it off for goals and the powerhouse shooters firing the ball into the net, while the less-talented players defer to someone else. You'll be caught up in the action as you "watch" players use their power, skill and savvy to make plays. Goalies have their own special ratings, designed to make the real-life star net-minders shine on your table top the just way they do on the pro league floor! Easy-to-play, but amazingly detailed--THAT'S Lacrosse Blast Pro Indoor Lacrosse simulation board game!

Expansion to the base game which allows the Acrobatic Cat variant to be played, as well as a standalone game using just the components of the expansion.

The standalone game is for 2 players and comprises of the stacking mechanic of the original game. The actions on the dice are different though, and there aren't any cat tokens in the game.

For playing the Acrobatic Cat variant you need the components of the original game. Apply stickers from the Plus game to the backsides of the cat tokens from the original game. The stickers contain special acrobatic actions for the cats to perform.

The cards from Cat Tower Plus can also be used to play the original game with up to 6 players.

Integrates with

    Cat Tower
    Cat Tower Lite

Forlorn Struggles is a DualPak game. It comes with two separate games in one package.

Operation Südwind is a two-player/solitaire game recreating the mid-February 1945 German offensive against the Soviet Bridgehead across the Garam River, in what is now southwestern Slovakia. It commenced on the morning of February 17. The German attack spearheads included a total of 44 formidable Tiger II tanks. Subsidiary attacks from across the Danube helped weaken the Soviet positions. 7th Guard Army defended stubbornly but was barely reinforced and by February 24th the Germans cleared the bridgehead. The Germans won a clear-cut operational victory but they incurred hard-to-replace losses. In the grand scheme of things Operation Südwind was a localized, and only temporary setback ,for the Soviets.

Operation Gemse is a two-player/solitaire game recreating the fierce early March German offensive in Oberlausitz and lower Siliesia against the unsuspecting Soviet 3rd Guard Tank Army commanded by General Rybalko. Securing Lauban and the surrounding area was deemed critical for a possible relief of encircled Breslau. However the planned grand encirclement anchored on Naumburg soon proved too ambitious. Instead on March 5 the Führer-Grenadier and Führer-Begleit Panzer divisions completed their reduced pincer movement and met up in Sächsisch-Haugsdorf. By March 7th, the encircled Soviet 7th Guard Tank Corps was almost completely destroyed.

Will you save the Earth or conquer it? From his stronghold on Apokolips, Darkseid is moving his forces into position, preparing to seize control of the planet! Only the Justice League stands between him and total global dominion! Will they be able to defend the planet, or will it fall to the merciless minions of Apokolips? In the Justice League Strategy Game, play as Batman, Superman, Wonder Woman, or Cyborg, each with unique powers and abilities; or as Darkseid, the nigh-unstoppable super-villain.

Utilizing a unique, card-driven system where players select the powers they wish to use without knowing what the opposition is up to, the Justice League Strategy Game comes complete with five character miniatures (with Character Sheets) featuring SwitchClix technology, plus two Custom Justice League Dice, 160 Custom Game Tokens, 86 Game Cards, and 24 Crisis Tiles.

Hex Survival is a tactic game of survival set in fantasy world of Moffee, where you'll have to be the last man standing.

PLOT 
In order to complete his masterpiece, the perfect Zombie, Dr.Skelrt trapped Moffee's heroes in his laboratory. In order to survive, the heroes will have to fight each other and avoid zombification: only the last man (or woman, or orc, or boar) standing will earn freedom!

 GAMEPLAY 
Control your hero pawns and kill your adversaries while escaping their zombie version and collecting treasure cards, in a randomly-built HEXangonal map full of bonuses and maluses.
You'll have to collect treasure cards in order to attack your fellow adversaries or heal your own zombified pawns, to fire your gun, stab your opponents' back, trick, bite and infect them, and a lot more.
Being zombified hero is not the end, but just another beginning.

 OBJECTIVE 
Eliminate all your opponents and be the last survivor at the end of a round.

In Dungeon Bazar, the players are greedy merchants who try to earn money by selling equipment — weapons, armor and tools — to heroes who wish to fight against an old dragon in a nearby cave. What the heroes don't know, though, is that the merchants have an agreement with the dragon, since they're interested in keeping their source of income, the great lizard, alive.

Each player has a personal game board, and each turn they play, then reveal a number of Equipment cards. Each Hero card displays the hero's desired equipment and priorities. Once the cards are revealed, the heroes buy from the cheapest stand according to their priorities, as long as they have money.

The co-operative game Thunderbirds, released in 2015 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the cult hit TV show, features the iconic Thunderbirds machines and a high-octane world full of disasters and victims for players to rescue.

Set in the year 2065, Thunderbirds follows the exploits of International Rescue, a secret organization committed to saving human life, secretly founded and funded by the millionaire Tracy family, with the motto: ‘Never give in, at any cost!’ International Rescue has a host of technologically advanced land-, sea-, air-, and space-rescue vehicles and equipment ready to launch at a moment’s notice.

Racing to the rescue from a secret island base beneath the luxurious home of the Tracy family somewhere in the South Pacific Ocean, International Rescue defies government spies and criminals who want the secrets of their incredible machines for their own. To combat this threat, Lady Penelope, the Thunderbirds’ aristocratic English secret agent, and her chauffeur Parker lead a network of agents to uncover those behind the disasters caused by deliberate sabotage.

A criminal mastermind known as “The Hood”, operating from a temple deep in the Malaysian jungle and in possession of strange powers, often engineers events to allow him to spy on the Thunderbird machines with the goal of selling their secrets to the highest bidder.

The iconic Thunderbirds are designed by the Tracy family’s close friend “Brains” and are assigned to each of the five Tracy brothers:
- Thunderbird 1, piloted by Scott Tracy – a hypersonic rocket plane used for fast response and rescue-zone reconnaissance, and as a mobile control base.
- Thunderbird 2, piloted by Virgil Tracy – a supersonic VTOL carrier which transports their major rescue equipment in detachable pods.
- Thunderbird 3, piloted by Alan Tracy – a single-stage, vertically launched spacecraft
- Thunderbird 4, piloted by Gordon Tracy – a utility submersible for underwater rescue, launched from Thunderbird 2
- Thunderbird 5, manned by John Tracy – a space station in geo-stationary orbit that monitors calls for help from across Earth.

Finally, Lady Penelope has the iconic FAB 1, driven by Parker – a pink, amphibious car.

Thunderbirds is a cult 1960s British science-fiction television series, created by Gerry and Sylvia Anderson. It was produced using a combination of marionette puppetry and scale-model special effects, which was dubbed “Supermarionation”. Two series, totaling thirty-two 50-minute episodes, were produced, along with two films using the same techniques.

Players will work together using Thunderbirds characters and vehicles to complete rescue missions and save the day.

Soqquadro is an innovative party game in which what's happening away from the table is as important as what's happening on it.

The game takes place in real-time. You draw a card from a deck and search for an object that satisfies the request on the card. The cards come in three colors to identify their difficulty level. When you find the object, place it on the table, move your pawn one step further on the score board and draw another card. When a pawn crosses a Challenge Line for the first time, the game stops for a while and a Challenge is played. The game ends when a pawn reaches or crosses the 16th box on the score board.

Cat Tower Lite is a 2 player version of the original Cat Tower game. Cats cards have to be stacked in special ways as dictated by the dice. The first player to have placed all his cards is the winner.

Cat Tower Lite has fewer cards than the original game. It also doesn't have the cat tokens of the big game. The dice is different too and has different actions for the players to perform.

The cards from Cat Tower Lite can also be used to play the original game with up to 6 players.

Integrates with

    Cat Tower
    Cat Tower Plus

The Visitors are coming, hellbent on world domination.

The Visitors is a cooperative 1 to 4 player game where the players are sent to a haunted manor with the objective of stop any manifestation of their arrival. Players take turn eliminating the haunting from the rooms of the manor and dealing with whatever Visitor that might appear.

The game ends after all the Visit cards have been used, meaning that they have successfully managed to stop their invasion. It will also end if 3 Visitors are present in the board at the same time, as they have become too strong to be defeated now.

Players are allocated 3 action points on their turn, and can choose to move to an adjacent room or to use a trinket in order to destroy a manifestation. Each Visitor brought on to the board makes the game harder as more Visit cards have to be drawn, with the extra effect of speeding up gameplay.

With a modular board and rules that allow for difficulty tweaking, no two playthroughs will be the same!

Dilemma is a two-player strategy game in which players compete by moving pawns around the board to collect tiles worth varying points.

The 49 tiles are placed in a preset pattern on a 7x7 grid, and two pawns are placed on top of two tiles in the central diagonal. One player can move the pawns along columns, while the other moves them along rows. Players cannot move the same pawn they moved the previous turn, so strategy is built around knowing which choices your opponent has next, and working to make those choices miserable — thus putting them in a dilemma. Some of the tiles affect the board when collected: moving tiles or pawns, returning pieces to the board, or stealing tiles from an opponent. When neither player can move, the game ends and whoever has the most points wins.

Skillful maneuvering and forethought are the name of the game in this engaging, classical board game.
